contentrichtext.text: {{italic title}} '''''Hit the Deck''''' is a [[musical theater|musical]] with music by [[Vincent Youmans]], lyrics by [[Clifford Grey]] and [[Leo Robin]] and book by [[Herbert Fields]].<ref name="blogspot1927">{{cite web|last=Soul |first=Keeping |url=http://malcolmlowryatthe19thhole.blogspot.com/2010/12/hit-deck-1927.html |title=Malcolm Lowry @ The 19th Hole: ''Hit The Deck'' 1927 |publisher=Malcolmlowryatthe19thhole.blogspot.com |date=5 December 2010|accessdate=21 February 2012}}</ref> It was based on the play ''[[Shore Leave (play)|Shore Leave]]'' by [[Hubert Osborne]]. Overall, it ran for 352 performances.<ref name="blogspot1927"/> The title refers to a [[nautical]] [[slang]] term that means to prepare for action (general) or to drop to a prone position on the ground (as a defensive response to hostile fire). The original production was staged at the [[Belasco Theatre]] on [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] on April 25, 1927. [[Charles King (vaudevillian)|Charles King]] played Bilge, [[Louise Groody]] played Loulou and [[Paul Lannin]] directed. The production ran for 352 performances.<ref>[http://ibdb.com/production.php?id=10292 ''Hit the Deck''], IBDB database, accessed 16 March 2012</ref> The first London production opened at the [[Hippodrome, London|Hippodrome]] on July 3, 1927 and ran for 277 performances. It starred [[Stanley Holloway]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gettyimages.co.uk/detail/3092417/Hulton-Archive |title=Stanley Holloway The English Entertainer In ''Hit The Deck'' |publisher=Gettyimages.co.uk |date=1927-07-03 |accessdate=2012-02-21}}</ref><ref>"Hit the Deck", ''The Times'', 4 November 1927, p. 7</ref> In ''[[The Manchester Guardian]]'', [[Ivor Brown]] praised Holloway for a singing style "which coaxes the ear rather than clubbing the head."<ref>Brown, Ivor. "Hit the Deck", ''The Manchester Guardian'', 4 November 1927, p. 15</ref> ==Songs== ;Act I *Join the Navy – Loulou, Gobs and Girls *What's a Kiss Among Friends? – Toddy, Charlotte, Alan and Girls *Harbor of My Heart – Loulou and Bilge *Shore Leave – Chorus *Lucky Bird – Lavinia *Looloo – Loulou and Boys *Why, Oh Why? – Charlotte and Chorus *[[Sometimes I'm Happy (Sometimes I'm Blue)]] – Loulou and Bilge ;Act II *Hallelujah! – Lavinia and Chorus *Hallelujah! (Reprise) –Lavinia *Looloo (Reprise) –Loulou and Boys *Utopia – Loulou and Bunny ==Film adaptations== [[File:Ann Miller and Tony Martin in Hit The Deck (Trailer).png|thumbnail|1955 film, "Hit The Deck"]] Two films based on the musical were made. The first was [[Hit the Deck (1930 film)|in 1930]] and starred [[Jack Oakie]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://movies.nytimes.com/movie/95367/Hit-the-Deck/overview |title=New York Times: Hit the Deck |accessdate=2008-08-18|work=NY Times | first=Mordaunt | last=Hall}}</ref> It was [[Hit the Deck (1955 film)|remade in 1955]] with a slightly different screenplay and differently named characters. It starred [[Jane Powell]] and [[Tony Martin (entertainer)|Tony Martin]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://movies.nytimes.com/movie/22630/Hit-the-Deck/overview |title=New York Times: Hit the Deck |accessdate=2008-08-18|work=NY Times}}</ref> ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.henrysvaudeville.com/Art/HBWhitthedeckClose.jpg Picture of Theater with production of Hit the Deck] {{Herbert Fields}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hit The Deck (Musical)}} [[Category:1927 musicals]]
